[Music]
The Cranberries wouldn't have become
famous if it wasn't for Dolores there's
no question about it there was something
about Dolores and her innocence she
lived in Limerick had never been outside
of Limerick and didn't know anything of
the world she's so innocent and so naive
and so unworldly and was suddenly
playing concerts to seventeen and
eighteen thousand people she grew up
very quickly I think a lot of people
maybe felt they were like a little bit
like her and the voice is one thing that
seemed to connect with so many people
[Music]
I first met Dolores in I think it was
1990 or 1991 the radio station I worked
for put on a series of gigs around the
country one of the bands we had on was a
band who had changed their name they had
been called The Cranberries saw us which
is a terrible name for a band
and but tonight they were called The
Cranberries and Dolores never once
looked at the audience she had her back
to the audience the whole time because
she was very kind of shy and very
frightened of the whole thing I mean
when we last talked to each other yeah
you were just beginning yeah what was
the secret how did you do it um we just
went to America and spent six months
five months to her and there is it yeah
and uh it just kind of just kept going
up and open up one of the most important
things about The Cranberries is timing
grunge was happening in America and
Britpop was happening over in this part
of the world in the middle of that early
90s tough came something a little bit
different it's something ethereal I
think you could nearly say something
that was for people who weren't really
into the kind of noise or the torn jeans
of grunge they just wanted some music
that would be a soundtrack to them
growing up between the ages of about 16
and 21 and the cranberries were one of
the few bands giving them something that
was really pure pop that was quite
heavenly been at the help of MTV they
just you know sold platinum after
platinum album
